benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/emails - Retrieve an account emails

covered: Valid Request: TC01 verifies successful retrieval, status 200, content-type application/json and basic schema fields.
Empty Response: TC02 and TC04 cover accounts with no emails and non-existent-but-valid UUID returning an empty array.
Input Validation: TC03 covers invalid accountId format (UUID pattern) and expected 400 response.
Authorization: TC05 covers missing/invalid auth token behavior (401/403).
Error Conditions: TC06 covers service-unavailable (503) and TC09 covers transient failures/retry behavior.
Security: TC10 and TC11 cover SQL injection and XSS attempts in the accountId path parameter.

Edge cases / data correctness: TC12 covers special/unicode characters in emails; TC08 covers very large result sets (functional large-result behavior) and TC13 covers concurrent requests (basic performance/concurrency).
Query Parameters: TC07 verifies that unexpected query parameters are ignored (robustness to extra params).
Backward-compatibility & accessibility: TC14 and TC15 exercise response compatibility and clarity/machine-readable error messages.
gaps: Pagination: No scenarios test pagination (limit, offset/page, page size) or behavior when results are paginated; large-results TC08 assumes a single full response rather than paging.
Caching Behavior: No tests check caching headers (ETag, Last-Modified, Cache-Control) or conditional requests (If-None-Match / 304 handling).
Rate Limiting / Throttling: No tests validate rate-limit responses (e.g., 429) or behavior under high request rates beyond functional concurrency tests.
Server Error Handling (500): No explicit test for internal server errors (e.g., database failure -> 500) and how errors are surfaced to clients.
Schema/Field Validation: Tests assert presence of expected fields but do not validate types, required/optional fields, or full JSON schema conformance for AccountEmail objects.
Response Consistency & Ordering: No tests verify deterministic ordering of returned emails or stable pagination cursors (if applicable).
Content-negotiation / Headers: Apart from one Content-Type check in TC01, headers and content-negotiation are not comprehensively tested across scenarios.
Rate / Performance SLAs: TC08 and TC13 mention acceptable limits but do not define measurable assertions for response-time bounds, nor stress/soak tests for longer durations.
recommendations: Add pagination tests: requests with limit/offset or page/pageSize parameters, verify page counts, next/previous links or cursors, and behavior when requesting page beyond range.
Add caching tests: verify Cache-Control and ETag headers on successful responses; test conditional GETs using If-None-Match and assert 304 when appropriate.
Add rate-limiting tests: simulate rapid bursts and sustained high request rates to assert 429 responses and relevant Retry-After headers, plus graceful degradation behavior.
Add server-error simulations: test handling of downstream failures (DB/network) and assert 500 responses with safe, machine-readable error bodies (no internal stack traces).
Add strict JSON schema validation: include tests that validate types, required fields, allowable values (e.g., isActive boolean), and that extra/missing fields are handled per the contract.
Add tests for deterministic ordering or explicit ordering parameters (if the API promises ordering), and tests that combine pagination + sorting.
Expand header testing: verify Content-Type across all responses, accept header handling, and any API-version headers (TC14 touches compatibility but tests should validate header-based behavior).
Add negative performance tests: define and assert explicit response-time SLAs for large-result and concurrent scenarios, and include stress/soak tests to detect memory/leak issues.
Add rate-limiting and caching interactions: test behavior when cached responses are served under high load and when conditional requests coincide with resource updates.
